organization.title: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Department of Commerce

name: periodic-bowhead-whale-aerial-surveys-by-the-usdi-minerals-management-service-in-the-bering-chu
notes: The Minerals Management Service (MMS), previously Bureau of LandnManagement, has funded fall bowhead whale aerial surveys in this areaneach year since 1978, using a repeatable protocol from 1982 to thenpresent. Bowhead monitoring by MMS Environmental Studies Section, AlaskanOuter Continental Shelf (OCS) Region, normally overlaps thenSeptember-October

season when offshore drilling andngeophysical exploration are feasible and when the fall subsistence huntnfor bowhead whales takes place near Kaktovik, Nuiqsut, and Barrow,nAlaska.nnThe primary survey aircraft was a de Havilland Twin Otter Series 300.nThe aircraft was equipped with three medium-size bubble windows thatnafforded complete viewing of the track-line. Geographic positions of thenaircraft were logged onto a laptop computer from a Global NavigationnSystem (1982-1991) or a Global Positioning System (1992-2000). Prior ton1992, many surveys in Block 12 (See Browse Graphic) were conducted fromna Grumman Turbo Goose Model G21G.nnAll bowhead (and beluga) whales observed were recorded, along withnincidental sightings of other marine mammals. Particular emphasis wasnplaced on regional surveys to assess large-area shifts in the migrationnpathway of bowhead whales and on the coordination of effort andnmanagement of data necessary to support seasonal offshore-drilling andnseismic-exploration regulations. The selection of survey blocks to benflown on a given day was nonrandom, based primarily on criteria such asnobserved and predicted weather conditions over the study area andnoffshore oil-industry activities. Otherwise, the project attempted tondistribute effort fairly evenly east-to-west across the entire studynarea. Aerial coverage favored inshore survey blocks (See BrowsenGraphic), since bowheads were rarely sighted north of these blocks innprevious surveys (1979-1986). Surveys were flown at a target altitude ofn458 m in order to maximize visibility and to minimize potentialndisturbance to marine mammals. Flights were normally aborted when cloudnceilings were consistently less than 305 m or the wind force wasnconsistently above Beaufort 4.nnDaily flight patterns were based on sets of non-repeating transect gridsncomputer-generated for each survey block. Transect grids were derived byndividing each survey block into sections 30 minutes of longitude across.nOne of the minute marks along the northern edge of each section wasnselected at random then connected by a straight line to a similarlynselected endpoint along the southern edge of that same section. Thisnprocedure was followed for all sections of that survey block. Thesentransect legs were then connected alternately at their northernmost ornsouthernmost ends to produce one continuous flight grid within eachnsurvey block. Gridlines were occasionally lengthened to cover both anninshore block and the block north of it. Lines were occasionallyntruncated due to extended poor visibility or to avoid potentialninterference with subsistence whaling activities. For bowheadsnencountered

, the aircraft sometimes circled for a brief (<n10 min) period to observe behavior, obtain better estimates of theirnnumbers, and/or determine whether calves were present. Any new groupsnsighted when circling were recorded as

title: Periodic bowhead whale aerial surveys by the USDI/Minerals Management Service in the Bering, Chukchi and Beaufort Seas, April 1979 - October 2001 (NODC Accession 0001139)
